Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Tracking iron & reactive oxygen species throughout infection of maize by a fungal necrotroph Cochliobolus heterostrophus

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF-EAPSI program is intended to not only accomplish research goals, but also send graduate students in America abroad to establish cultural and professional ties internationally. Working with the fungal endophyte Epichloe festucae in Dr. Barry Scott's lab at Massey University in New Zealand, I gained experience working with the subcellular reactive oxygen species (ROS) dyes nitroblue tetrazolium and diamonobenzidine. Epichloe is a symbiont of rye grass that confers several benefits to the host plant, and is of agricultural importance because of its production of small molecule toxins that cause disease when consumed by livestock. Working with several of Dr. Scott's knockout strains for different ROS related genes, I confirmed abnormal staining with these dyes using techniques commonplace in this laboratory. In addition, I gained experience using confocal microscopy at the Manawatu Microscopy Center on samples prepared and fixed in the United States. Since returning to the States, my experience in New Zealand has allowed me to use the techniques I learned to stain for ROS with my own fungal pathogen Cochliobolus heterostrophus, which I could not transfer to New Zealand. In addition, I developed contacts not only at Massey University, but at Agresearch, a leading agricultural research group in New Zealand, as well as the MacDiarmid institute. As per the programs goals, I also experienced much of New Zealand's culture.
